conclusion: Understanding the thermodynamics problem with a PV diagram showing a cyclic process for an ideal gas.
Cycle goes from A to B to C to D and back to A with pressure on y-axis and volume on x-axis.
Pressure at point A is 1 x 10^5 Pa, and at point D is 0.75 x 10^5 Pa. Volumes at points C and D are 4 L and 3 L, respectively.
Net change in internal energy over the cycle is zero, so net heat absorbed equals net work done: Q = W.
Goal is to calculate net work done by the gas during one complete cycle.
Net work done in a cyclic process is the area enclosed by the cycle in the PV diagram.
Cycle proceeds from A to B (isobaric expansion), B to C (isochoric cooling), C to D (isobaric compression), and D to A (isochoric heating).
Confirming pressures and volumes at points A, B, C, and D.
Calculate work done from A to B: W = p ΔV.
Convert units for work calculation: 1 L = 1 x 10^-3 m³.
Work done from A to B is 100 J.
Work done from B to C is zero (isochoric process).
Calculate work done from C to D: W = p ΔV with negative ΔV.
Work done from C to D is -75 J.
Work done from D to A is zero (isochoric process).
